chapter.title: Utilizing resources skills defined
chapter.content:
To define the competency of utilizing resources, let’s look at the comparable skill of resource management defined in the Employability Skills Framework. This skill encompasses a broad range of resources to be well-utilized and well-managed, including:

  • time;
  • money;
  • materials; and
  • personnel.

Selecting the appropriate tools or technology solutions for a given task and properly handling and maintaining them are also relevant components of utilizing resources (National Network of Business and Industry Associations, 2014).

Clearly, in a workplace setting the responsibility for managing money, personnel, or materials will vary greatly depending on one’s role. Nevertheless, the focus is on thoughtful assessment, selection, and allocation of resources within one’s control, including managing one’s personal time and money effectively.

In the classroom context, learners can practice managing personnel when they participate in team projects, delegate tasks, and reflect on their own participation and accountability to the group. Similarly, learners can practice managing money by creating a household budget.

chapter.title: Classroom activity example: Utilizing resources and using information
chapter.content:
Here’s one idea for integrating the competencies of utilizing resources and using information into classroom instruction.

The class plans a visit to the local public library, CareerOneStop Center, or other community resource. Before the visit, they generate a list of questions they have about the services available and requirements for participation. Afterwards, students identify one service or resource that they’d like to explore further or in which they’d like to participate.

chapter.title: Using information competencies defined
chapter.content:
According to the Employability Skills Framework, using information is about developing and using procedures and tools for:

  • locating information;
  • selecting information;
  • organizing information;
  • analyzing information; and
  • sharing information.

Critical thinking and analysis, digital literacy, and communication skills are all embedded in the process of using information effectively.

Click the arrow to continue to What the research says about using information competencies.

chapter.title: What the research says about using information competencies
chapter.content:
Organizing information involves using graphic organizers and outlines to categorize and prepare for analysis, summary, and explanation. Using information goes beyond memorization and requires students to actively engage with the material, question it, and summarize it in their own words—a key practice in developing deeper learning (Pellegrino & Hilton et al., 2010, p. 10).

How learners code, organize, and store information in their memories so that it can be retrieved and applied (transferred) is a feature that distinguishes novice learners from experts. Research indicates that these strategies can be taught (Pellegrino et al., p. 5).

chapter.title: Classroom activity example: Using information, digital literacy, and critical thinking competencies and skills
chapter.content:
Here’s how one teacher integrates the competencies of utilizing resources and using information, as well as critical thinking skills into classroom instruction.

Following a class discussion about the cost of cell phones and service plans, students generate a list of questions about how to choose the most economical cell phone service plan. The teacher delegates tasks among the students for researching local providers. Students use a comparison table to collect the information (via web search, visit, or call to store). Finally, students report their findings to the class to compare and evaluate the different plans.

chapter.title: Working with others competency defined
chapter.content:
The attributes of working with others can be found in the Employability Skills Framework under the broad heading of Effective Relationships and the subheading of Interpersonal skills. Interpersonal skills include:

  • understands teamwork and works with others;
  • responds to customer needs;
  • exercises leadership;
  • negotiates to resolve conflicts; and
  • respects individual differences.

Managing (personnel) resources is echoed here in the emphasis on working with, leading, and delegating to teams.

Click the forward arrow to continue to What the research says about working with others.

chapter.title: What the research says about working with others
chapter.content:
Regardless of the job or occupation, no matter the level of academic, technical, and professional skill and expertise one holds, success in the 21st century workforce requires the ability to work with others and “to deal with the challenges, relationships, transitions, and social systems that make up working life” (Shechtman et al., 2016, p. i). While communication skills are not explicitly named in the WIOA definition of workforce preparation skills, they are critical attributes for effectively working with others.

Opportunities for students to learn how to work with peers on substantive team or collaborative projects equips them with important workforce preparation skills. Team or collaborative projects also enhance the content learning itself because learning is inherently a social process where we build a sense of connection, take risks, test out ideas in conversation, and debate (Ibid., p. 20).

chapter.title: Classroom Activity Example: Self-Management and Using Information
chapter.content:
Here’s how one teacher integrates the competencies of working with others into her classroom instruction.

The teacher leads a class brainstorming session to discuss the advantages and disadvantages of working as a team. She then divides the class into project teams to discuss and solve a set of math problems. The teacher also assigns roles for keeping the team on task – facilitator, note-taker, and time keeper. After the groups work on the problems, the teacher reviews their solutions to the problem. To wrap up the activity, the teacher asks students to reflect on the team process, the effectiveness of role assignments, and what worked and didn’t work.

What kinds of responses do you think this teacher received? Have you tried a similar activity with your class? If so, you are already finding ways to integrate the workforce preparation activities into your classroom instruction!

chapter.title: Understanding systems competency defined
chapter.content:
The Partnership for 21st Century Skills (P21), explains that, in general, systems thinking is the ability to understand and “analyze how parts of a whole interact with each other to produce overall outcomes” (P21, 2015a & b). The Employability Skills Framework states that systems thinking involves “understanding, using, monitoring, and improving systems” (2015). Systems may be technical, social, organizational, cultural, or institutional.

Systems thinking can mean understanding how the components of a technical or procedural system work together. It can also be applied to the organizational structure of a team, assessing one’s own role in a team, and how the team can function as a whole.

For example, Certified Nursing Assistants (CNA) and Patient Care Technicians (PCTs) each have a defined role, as do the doctors and nurses they work with. They are all a part of a hospital system, and must understand staff interactions and other processes to understand the system.

Click the forward arrow to continue to What the research says about understanding systems.

chapter.title: What the research says about understanding systems
chapter.content:
Systems thinking also refers to understanding organizational and institutional systems. This sort of institutional and social system thinking begins with the understanding that systems are everywhere. Schools, colleges, workplaces, and even communities and families each have their own:

  • systems;
  • organizational cultures;
  • policies;
  • procedures; and
  • norms of conduct and communication.

Institutional knowledge and the ability to navigate systems are needed to function effectively in different settings and organizations (ATLAS-Academic Career & Employability Skills, 2013; Shechtman et al., 2016, p. 10).

More Information

CareerOneStop offers a brief video on systems (click the “Using Systems” link).

chapter.title: Classroom activity example: Understanding systems
chapter.content:
Here’s how one teacher integrates the competencies of working with others into her classroom instruction.

Here’s an example of integrating the competency of understanding systems into classroom instruction.

Students read three brief case studies in which someone has a similar complaint or problem in three different local settings – a school, workplace, city/town. Next, the students research (via web search, phone calls, employee and student handbook) the process for reporting the issue in each of those settings. After gathering and sharing the information, they compare results and describe the differences between the settings.

chapter.title: Skills necessary for successful transition into and completion of postsecondary education or training/employment
chapter.content:
This is a category of skills included in the WIOA definition of workforce preparation activities that might be seen as a catch-all for any skill that was not explicitly mentioned. These skills include:

  • college and career readiness skills;
  • job readiness skills; and
  • job search skills.

Click the forward arrow to continue to College and career readiness skills.

chapter.title: College and career readiness skills
chapter.content:
The National College Transition Network (NCTN) identifies four areas of college and career readiness  that define “true readiness:”

  • personal;
  • career;
  • academic; and
  • college knowledge.

These four broad areas represent the types of knowledge, skills, and preparation students need to be successful as they pursue their educational goals and career pathway.

Review the skills listed under each of the four areas before moving on. As you examine the skills in each area, consider how they align and intersect with the skills in the other areas and with the workforce preparation activities.

chapter.title: Transition skills include job readiness and job search skills
chapter.content:
Finally, there is a set of workforce preparation skills typically referred to as job readiness or job search skills that have not been explicitly delineated thus far. These include how to:

  • conduct a job search using multiple methods (e.g., networking, online applications, job fairs);
  • write and format an effective resume;
  • prepare for a job interview; and
  • behave in a professional manner (e.g., punctuality, appropriate dress, etiquette, etc.).

As with all of the workforce preparation skills, these skills can be taught in combination with others and integrated into academic instruction. For example, resume writing and completing online job searches and applications can be an outcome of activities aimed at increasing students’ basic academic skills as well as their use of technology.

chapter.title: Self-Management and Self-Regulation used interchangeably
chapter.content:
In the context of learning, the term self-management is often used interchangeably with the term self-regulation. Effective and persistent learners are found to employ metacognitive strategies and self-regulation skills, such as:

  • asking questions;
  • taking notes;
  • analyzing the task at hand;
  • setting learning goals;
  • managing time on task; and
  • monitoring progress.

More Info

For more information on metacognition, strategies, and processes, explore the TEAL Fact Sheet on Metacognitive Processes.

chapter.title: College knowledge and career readiness transition skills
chapter.content:
College knowledge and career readiness offer examples of important transition skills that are not explicitly referenced in the workforce preparation activities, such as:

  • applying for postsecondary education or training;
  • understanding the costs of postsecondary education or training;
  • applying for financial aid;
  • applying for a job, potentially using federally-funded resources and websites designed to help adults find employment; and
  • understanding what is needed to succeed and complete postsecondary education or training programs.
